page.title: 03ALRESFORD WATERCRESS GROWING
page.content: {Watercress}has grown wild in the area for hundreds of years,but it was the railway opening in 1865 that opened up the industry.The perishable cress could be taken to the station in the afternoon and be on sale at Covent Garden in the early hours. It takes about 5 or 6 weeks for the cress to grow.The process is labour intensive as it is picked and bunched by hand.They must pick the cress before it flowers and goes yellow. The cress 'beds' are constructed of concrete and in general fed by bore holes in the Chalk which deliver the water at a constant 10 degrees C.The water is kept running through the beds and grids etc. at the higher end keep out most fish,sticks and things which may damage the cress.It is sold at the 'beds' for about 18p. a bunch.
